Award.AwardTitle: Regulation of Pseudomonas syringae Virulence by Plant-Derived Chemical Signals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacterial diseases of plants cause significant losses in overall yield and marketability of many economically-important US crops. Although plants possess an immune system that can provide effective resistance against infection, bacteria have evolved sophisticated counter-measures that can effectively suppress these host defenses. As a result, a major determinant of infection outcome is how rapidly both bacteria and host plant can deploy their respective virulence and defense strategies. This project will investigate the molecular basis for chemical signaling events that occur between plants and bacteria at the onset of infection, with a focus on how pathogenic bacteria perceive plant-derived metabolite signals to begin their infection process. Non-specific antimicrobials such as copper sprays and broad-spectrum antibiotics are frequently used to control bacterial diseases in crops. This project will provide a deeper understanding of host perception mechanisms in bacteria that could lead to development of specific chemical inhibitors of this process, thereby providing alternative methods to control disease and potentially improve crop fitness. The project will also provide opportunities for undergraduate students at smaller resource-limited colleges to gain research experience through internships in the investigator's laboratory. Furthermore, a workshop on proteomics methodology will be developed and delivered by the investigator as part of a two-week summer STEM camp for high school students.

Genes encoding the virulence-promoting type III secretion system (T3SS) of the plant pathogen Pseudomonas syringae must be expressed at early stages of infection for this bacterium to be fully virulent. In previous work, the investigator identified plant-derived metabolites that induce the expression of T3SS-encoding genes in P. syringae. Although the bioactive plant metabolites are potent enhancers of virulence, how they are perceived by P. syringae to initiate expression of its T3SS is not known. A primary objective of this project is to elucidate the genetic basis for host recognition by P. syringae with a goal of identifying potential receptor proteins that are directly involved in perceiving host metabolite signals. A second objective is elucidate why a P. syringae gacA- mutant that hyper-expresses its T3SS is less virulent, with the goal of understanding how P. syringae coordinates the deployment of virulence factors to maximize pathogenicity. Lastly, exogenous application of T3SS-inducing metabolites during P. syringae infection of Arabidopsis suppresses enhanced resistance mediated by plant pathogen recognition receptors (PRRs), suggesting a mechanism of PRR-dependent resistance may be the removal of these metabolite signals or interference with their perception. This project will investigate if extracellular levels of the bioactive metabolites change following PRR activation in Arabidopsis plants. Insights into this possible mechanism of plant defense may lead to the development of engineered crop plants that deploy PRR-mediated defenses in a more effective and targeted manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to understand inter-kingdom chemical communication between plants and the pathogenic bacterium Pseudomonas syringae. Diseases caused by bacterial pathogens are a major threat to agriculture. Therefore, this area of research is foundational to developing new crop protection strategies and increasing global food security. To cause disease, P. syringae uses a syringe-like weapon called the type III secretion system (T3SS) to inject immune-suppressing proteins into host cells. A long-standing question is how P. syringae detects host plants to initiate T3SS deployment. This project builds on the previous discovery that specific metabolites exuded from plants induce T3SS-encoding genes, and that levels of these plant metabolites are an important determinant of infection outcomes. In this project, we identified multiple signaling components in P. syringae responsible for detecting and responding to host signals, including a complete signaling pathway leading from perception of two specific host metabolites directly to regulation of T3SS-associated genes. We also investigated changes in metabolite composition of defense-elicited leaf tissue, setting the stage for a more complete understanding of how plants may defend against pathogens.

As a starting point for this project we carried out a genetic screen to identify genes required for P. syringae to respond to plant-derived metabolites. This screen resulted in the discovery of a novel signaling pathway consisting of periplasmic substrate binding protein AatJ, receptor protein AauS, and response requlator AauR. We showed that this AatJ-AauS-AauR pathway connects perception of two host-derived amino acids, aspartate and glutamate, directly to regulation of T3SS genes through a conserved AauR-binding DNA sequence found upstream of the T3SS regulatory operon hrpRS.  Remarkably, our data indicate that essentially all strains of P. syringae - including pathogens of major crops such as tomato and bean - use this AauS-AauR pathway to detect their hosts, suggesting that interfering with this pathway may be a universal approach to mitigate all P. syringae diseases. From our genetic screen we also identified a transcriptional regulator named SetA that is important for T3SS deployment in response to host-derived sugars. Our results suggest SetA may directly function as a host signal receptor and, combined with our studies of AauS-AauR, reveal previously unknown complexity in host signal perception and integration.

This project also investigated the role of the GacS-GacA two-component system in regulating P. syringae virulence. GacS-GacA is an important regulator of virulence in many phytopathogenic bacteria, yet its role in P. syringae was not clearly defined. Data generated by this project redefined GacS-GacA as a negative regulator, rather than a positive regulator, of T3SS expression in P. syringae, and revealed that GacS-GacA is not required for virulence of DC3000. Rather, based on further characterization of a gacA::Tn5 mutant, our results uncovered roles for two genes, anmK and uvrC, in DC3000 virulence. This work provides a revised model for GacS-GacA function that serves as an important foundation for future investigations of this important virulence regulator.

 A third objective of this proposal was to investigate if T3SS-inducing metabolites change in abundance in plant tissues in response to pathogen infection. Using GC-MS metabolomics, we identified changes in the metabolite content of defense-elicited plant tissue, including several T3SS-inducing compounds. These data support the hypothesis that plants alter their metabolome as a means to limit infection, and set the stage for future experiments aimed at uncovering the molecular basis for these changes.

In addition to generating new scientific knowledge, this project advanced multiple Broader Impacts objectives. Several early career scientists, including 2 PhD students, 1 postdoctoral researcher and 1 faculty research assistant were trained in advanced molecular plant pathology techniques, thereby increasing the quality of the US workforce. To broaden access and participation in research, four undergraduates from primarily undergraduate institutions and one high school student participated in summer-long internships, conducting independent research. Two additional undergraduates carried out independent research related to this project during the academic year. In 2016 and 2017 the PI contributed proteomics-related programming for two summer high school STEM camps at Oregon State University that served 48 students. In 2018 and 2019 the PI was the principal organizer of two three day residential STEM camps at Oregon State that intentionally drew from both urban and rural schools that serve a high proportion of underserved students, as a means to promote diversity and inclusion across existing cultural divides. These camps hosted a total of 30 students and 4 teachers, and included hands-on lab activities to teach fundamentals of molecular biology and bioinformatics.
